SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.
:box:“When he plowed, he drove his horses close to the fenland edge next to the water, so as to make use of every half inch of land.”
:box:“All this time, he hardly realized that his ill-gotten property, now increased to twelve acres or more, was itself a very shaky bit of real estate.”
Which conclusion is best supported by the sentences?

A.Choice: Ryer believes that trying new methods will make working on the farm easier.

Key.Rationale: There is no textual support for this conclusion.

B.Choice: Ryer is too busy with chores on the farm to pay attention to other events.

Key.Rationale: There is no textual support for this conclusion.

C.Choice: Ryer is too consumed by the desire to expand the farm to notice signs of danger.

Key.Rationale: The given sentences show that Ryer is reckless in his desire to make his farm bigger.

D.Choice: Ryer believes that the farm will become more stable as its size increases.

Key.Rationale: Even though the size of Ryer's farm does increase, the passage never implies that Ryer believes the farm will become more stabl

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story, drama, or poem interact (e.g., how the setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“About this time, heavy rains fell for many days and without ceasing, until all the region was reduced to pulp and the country seemed afloat.”
How does the description of the storm's effects most contribute to the development of the plot?

A.Choice: The description foreshadows the fate of Ryer's property.

Key.Rationale: Te use of the words “country seemed afloat” foreshadows how Ryer's property will be washed away.

B.Choice: The description foreshadows the path of Ryer's journey.

Key.Rationale: There is nothing in the given sentence to suggest the path of Ryer's journey.

C.Choice: The description explains why Ryer falls into the water.

Key.Rationale: Although Ryer does fall into the water, the given sentence does not explain why he does so.

D.Choice: The description explains why Ryer is able to acquire land.

Key.Rationale: Although Ryer was able to acquire land by adding pieces from his neighbors' properties, these actions occur before the heavy rains come in the passage.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.
:box:“The dykes appeared ready to burst.”
:box:“Yet none of this i͟m͟p͟e͟n͟d͟i͟n͟g trouble worried Ryer, whose greed grew by what it fed upon.”
What is the meaning of the word i͟m͟p͟e͟n͟d͟i͟n͟g as it is used in the sentence?

Key.Rationale: The phrase “ready to burst” helps the reader to conclude that “impending” means “about to occur.”
The context provided does not support this meaning.
The context provided does not support this meaning.
The context provided does not support this meaning.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“The mainland was every moment r͟e͟c͟e͟d͟i͟n͟g farther into the distance.”
What does the word r͟e͟c͟e͟d͟i͟n͟g mean as it is used in the sentence?

Key.Rationale: The context provided in the given sentence does not support this meaning.
The context provided in the given sentence does not support this meaning.
The phrase “farther into the distance” helps the reader to infer that the meaning of “receding” is “moving away.”
The context provided in the given sentence does not support this meaning.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“... the Van Boompjes' farm, now an accomplished traveler after its many adventures, shot into its old place.”
How is the metaphor being used in the sentence?

A.Choice: to show that the farm is a cause of the Van Boompjes' problems

Key.Rationale: Even though the idea may be somewhat true, the given metaphor does not support this inference.

B.Choice: to emphasize the length of time the farm has been floating on water

Key.Rationale: The words “accomplished” and “after its many adventures” suggest that the farm had experience and had been floating on water for a great amount of time.

C.Choice: to highlight the physical condition of the farm after floating on water

Key.Rationale: This choice does not make sense with the given metaphor and is not supported by textual evidence.

D.Choice: to reveal that the farm is an important part of the Van Boompjes' lives

Key.Rationale: This choice does not make sense with the given metaphor and is not supported by textual evidence.

Topics: Reading Literature - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
How does Pete's point of view differ from Ryer's point of view?

Key.Rationale: There is no text support for this option within the passage.
There is no text support for this option within the passage.
Pete's actions show that he has common sense and can solve problems quickly.
There is no text support for this option within the passage.

Content: Which sentences from the passage support the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “Pete, his stout son, who was not far away and had seen the tumble, ran to the house, launched a boat, and rowed quickly to the spot where he had last seen his father.”

Key.Rationale: This choice shows that Pete is able to react to problems quickly and make good decisions. By rowing to the spot where he had seen his father, Pete shows good problem-solving skills.

B.Choice: “Ryer was too mystified to get his bearings, but Pete knew the points of the compass.”

Key.Rationale: This choice shows that Pete is able to react to problems quickly and make good decisions. Knowing how to use a compass shows that Pete has real-world practical sense.

C.Choice: “Father and son were sitting in the hotel parlor, with their eyes down on the sandy floor, wondering how they were to pay for their next sandwich and coffee, for their money was all gone.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not relate to Pete being more sensible than this father.

D.Choice: “At once, Ryer, still stiff from his long, cold bath, hobbled out, and Pete ran before him.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not relate to Pete being more sensible than this father.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story, drama, or poem interact (e.g., how the setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
Which statement best describes the role of the setting in the passage?

A.Choice: The setting emphasizes the absurdity of the conflict.

Key.Rationale: The setting, a farm that floats away with a house and animals, seems absurd; therefore, the absurdity of the actual setting relates to the illogical idea of the farm floating away.

B.Choice: The setting highlights the heroism of the main character.

Key.Rationale: There is nothing majestic or dignified about the setting that would highlight the heroism of Ryer.

C.Choice: The setting creates doubt that the conflict will be resolved.

Key.Rationale: The setting does not relate to doubt.

D.Choice: The setting reveals the distinct personalities of the characters.

Key.Rationale: The setting does not relate to the distinct personalities of the characters.

Content: Which sentence from the passage best supports the answer in Part One? Choose one answer.

A.Choice: “There was once a Dutchman who lived in the province called Drenthe.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the correct answer in Part One since it does not represent the most absurd aspects of the setting.

B.Choice: “When his father was able to sit up and talk, Pete started to row back to the little wharf in front of his home.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the correct answer in Part One since it does not represent the most absurd aspects of the setting.

C.Choice: “A house, a woman, some girls, a dog, a cat, and a stork were on it and afloat.”

Key.Rationale: The sentence allows the reader to visualize the absurdity of the setting.

D.Choice: “On the farm, all the animals, from duck to stork and from dog to ox, now led happier lives.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the correct answer in Part One since it does not represent the most absurd aspects of the setting.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which sentence from the passage best illustrates the theme that people can learn from their mistakes?

A.Choice: “Yet although Ryer was rich, as wealth is reckoned in Drenthe, whence he had come, he was greedy for more.”

Key.Rationale: Although this option shows that Ryer was greedy, it does not explain how he learned from this mistake.

B.Choice: “The stingy fellow, as he fell overboard, bumped his head so hard on the plough beam that he lay senseless for a half hour.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not relate to people learning from their mistakes.

C.Choice: “As for the Van Boompjeses, in order to save a landlord's bill for beds, they slept in their house on board the farm.”

Key.Rationale: Although the family is able to problem solve how to save money on hotel expenses, this sentence does not show how they learn from a mistake.

D.Choice: “He sawed off, from time to time, portions of his big farm, and returned them home, with money paid as interest, to the owners.”

Key.Rationale: This choice shows that Ryer learns to change his greedy ways, given his decision to return the land he had taken and pay his neighbors for his actions.

SubTopics: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: The passage “Sowing Community” focuses on a family's participation in an art project. Write an essay analyzing the effect that the edible landscape project has had on the community. Use evidence from the passage to support your response.
Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) Everybody (this includes sixth, seventh, and eighth graders) is going to hear Professor McGregor speak about his research. (2) Facts about Science for Non-Scientists is the book that he wrote. (3) Neither the science teachers nor their students have read the book yet. (4) By next week, someone from each of the three grades have to be prepared to ask an interesting question about the topic.
Which change would correct the mistake in the paragraph?

A.Choice: Change i͟s to a͟r͟e in sentence 1.

Key.Rationale: Sentence 1 already has subject-verb agreement between “everybody” and “is.”

B.Choice: Change i͟s to a͟r͟e in sentence 2.

Key.Rationale: Sentence 2 has subject-verb agreement between “Facts about Science for Non-Scientists” and “is.”

C.Choice: Change h͟a͟v͟e to h͟a͟s in sentence 3.

Key.Rationale: Sentence 3 already has subject-verb agreement between “teachers”/“students” and “have.”

D.Choice: Change h͟a͟v͟e to h͟a͟s in sentence 4.

Key.Rationale: “Have” needs to be changed to “has” to ensure subject-verb agreement with “someone,” which is singular.

SubTopics: Choose words and phrases for effect.
Content: Which sentence is the most descriptive?

A.Choice: Waiting backstage, John was nervous about having to perform a solo in front of so many people at the annual music night at his school.

Key.Rationale: Even though this option says that John was “nervous,” this option does not describe his behavior as specifically as the best option.

B.Choice: He had practiced for days on end, trying to play the music as perfectly as he could.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not specifically describe John's surroundings or feelings.

C.Choice: In fact, he had memorized his solo weeks before the night of his performance because he had thought that doing so would help.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not specifically describe John's surroundings or feelings.

D.Choice: Feeling jittery, John stepped unsteadily onto the stage and into the glaring lights to brave a sea of faces in the audience.

Key.Rationale: The specific details allow the reader to understand best how John feels and what he sees.

SubTopics: Use a comma to separate coordinate adjectives (e.g., It was a fascinating, enjoyable movie but not He wore an old[,] green shirt).
Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) As the head of postal services, Benjamin Franklin established a profitable mail delivery system in colonial America. (2) The adventurous Franklin traveled some 1,600 miles between postal offices to mark all possible direct routes. (3) He had riders transport mail day and night for faster more productive delivery. (4) He also created a simpler and more standard rating system so postmasters could consistently calculate the price of postage.
Where should a comma be added?

Key.Rationale: “Profitable” and “mail delivery” do not function as coordinate adjectives in sentence 1.
“Possible” and “direct” do not function as coordinate adjectives in sentence 2.
A comma needs to be placed after “faster” in sentence 3 since “faster” and “more productive” are coordinate adjectives.
“Simpler” and “more standard” do not function as coordinate adjectives in sentence 4.

SubTopics: Use punctuation (e.g., commas, parentheses, dashes) to set off nonrestrictive/parenthetical elements.
Content: Read the sentence.
:box:The International Space Station a large satellite in outer space, orbits Earth at speeds of about 17,500 miles per hour.
Which revision should be made to the sentence?

Key.Rationale: “A large satellite in outer space” is a nonrestrictive clause, it should be set off with a comma after “Station.”
A dash is used to strongly emphasize a parenthetical element and often conveys a change in tone, which is not appropriate in this sentence.
No comma is needed after “speeds.”
Parentheses should not be placed around “miles per hour” since this phrase is necessary for the completion of the sentence and is not additional or unneeded information.
